column23: Our I-6 program is designed to train motivated candidates to become academic leaders in Thoracic Surgery. The first three years entail comprehensive training in prerequisites for cardiothoracic surgery, including general/vascular surgery, cardiology, and critical care. The last three years are devoted to extensive training in all aspects of cardiothoracic surgery. There is also an exceptional opportunity for interested trainees to earn a concurrent PhD.

column23: We have one of the most mature integrated thoracic programs in the country. Our I-6 provides excellent training with an integrated, multidisciplinary, competency-based and resident centric approach. Residents perform a full spectrum of adult cardiac, thoracic, congenital, lung transplant, open/ endovascular aortic and minimally invasive surgical techniques. Our graduates are well employed and fully competent to provide excellent patient care.

column23: Indiana University vascular surgery serves as the principal tertiary care referral network for vascular disease across the state. We support both an integrated vascular surgical training program (0+5 track with 2 years of research) and an independent vascular surgery fellowship program (5+2 program). Training is offered in 3 major health facilities that includes a university hospital, VA facility, as well as a county hospital.

column23: Our division has a longstanding commitment to educating future leaders in the field. We were the 4th 0+5 program in the country, offering excellent training in both open and endovascular techniques. We performed >125 aortic operations last year (40% open), 200 CEA, 145 leg bypasses, and >1000 endovascular procedures. We are committed to thorough, high quality training, in a friendly and respectful environment.

column23: The mission of the integrated vascular surgery residency program is to provide comprehensive training, knowledge and skills needed for independent practice of vascular surgery; including the assessment and management of patients with vascular disease, use of the vascular laboratory, critical care, open surgery, and endovascular procedures. The focus is clinically oriented with a strong foundation in all aspects of open vascular surgery, endovascular surgery, and core general surgery principles.

column23: Vascular surgery provides diagnosis/treatment of vascular disease from routine to highly complex cases. Education is considered a critical component for medical students/residents/fellows. The division engages patients with opportunities to participate in clinical trials offering them the only local access to newly developed treatment options. The clinical/academic strengths of vascular surgery form the foundation of continued success in achieving excellence in patient care/education/research.

column23: The goal of our training program is to provide a high quality education that appropriately prepares trainees to face future challenges in the field of vascular surgery. The faculty of the department of cardiothoracic and vascular surgery is committed to help each resident become independent and proficient in the management of all surgical and medical aspects of vascular disease. Trainees are exposed to the full spectrum of vascular disorders treated by both open and endovascular procedures.

column23: The UW Division of Vascular Surgery offers world-class training in cutting-edge techniques at multiple sites of practice. Our Integrated Residency (0+5) and traditional fellowship (5+2) produce surgeons capable of handling any vascular pathology. Each of our four sites of practice is unique, offering training in all facets of vascular disease. We're actively involved in all vascular traumas referred to the only Level I trauma center in the WWAMI region. Numerous opportunities for research exist.

column23: Over the course of the five-year clinical training period, vascular residents will spend a total of 24 months on core surgery rotations and 36 months on vascular surgery rotations. Residents are required to participate in 2 years of dedicated research experience. 4th year residents have the opportunity to participate in a global health elective in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Residents receive an annual well-being benefit of $500. Parental leave for parents allows for up to 6 weeks of paid leave.

column23: MCF residents are trained to lead their communities. Residents become proficient in robotic, laparoscopic, endourologic, prosthetic and reconstructive surgeries. MCF faculty subspecialize in oncology, endourology, incontinence, men's health, BPH, female pelvic surgery and pediatrics. Training is based on a mentorship model. Skill acquisition is individually paced and rewarded with early and sustained surgical exposure. Recent grads have logged 160 lap nephrectomies & 150 robotic prostatectomies,

column23: The philosophical framework of the program is to foster an environment of inquisitiveness and study recognizing that urology is a surgical subspecialty with a strong tradition of innovation and technological advancement. The relationship between attending and resident is one of mentoring, rather than traditionally hierarchical, and the working environment is team-oriented. The Program objective is to train the complete urologist and be fully prepared for a non-academic or academic career path.

column23: This is a 5-year categorical urology residency. Beginning in 2020-2021 the program will incorporate an unaccredited research year in the 4th year of residency training making it a 6-year program. Preceptorship training model. Supervised surgical skills training one hour per week, unlimited access to surgical simulators remainder of the week, including robotics.

column23: Our goal is to equip our residents for excellence in whatever career pathway they choose. We offer comprehensive clinical training alongside full-time faculty with expertise in oncology, endourology, robotics, andrology, reconstruction, female pelvic medicine and pediatric urology. Residents rotate at St Louis University Hospital, Cardinal Glennon Children's Hospital (both on the SLU medical campus) and St Mary's Medical Center, all of which share an integrated clinical information system.

column23: Urology program continues to expand with 20 faculty between three sites. Residents are assigned to a team of 2-5 faculty with graded responsibility for each year with senior residents assigned complex cases while juniors spend time doing simple cases and endoscopy. Residents spend 6 months with Concord urology and 6 months at the VA. There is a robust conference schedule with protected time. All urology residents participate in research and are encouraged to attend and present their research.

column23: Cooper University Hospital is the largest hospital in southern New Jersey, providing health services, medical education and clinical research in the southern NJ area and the Delaware Valley. The urology residency at Cooper is a vibrant 5 year program dedicated to providing high-quality, structured training. Weekly conferences, ongoing clinical rotations, unique research projects, and operating room experiences constitute the core of the curriculum. We look forward to reviewing your application!

column23: We pride ourselves on camaraderie amongst faculty and residents. We have faculty that are fellowship-trained in each of the urologic subspecialties and no fellows, allowing for a robust and diverse clinical experience. Our rotation schedule is based on a "mentor model." This allows for early, hands-on exposure to all subspecialties where residents gain an in-depth knowledge of their faculty's clinical and operative practice while taking care of patients pre-, intra- and post-operatively.

column23: Unity Health WCMC has one of the largest GME programs in Arkansas. Our goal is to provide our residents with exposure to a variety of general medical patients, both inpatient and outpatient, teach them the basics of quality care, and mentor them to become passionate physicians as they transition from medical school to their training programs.  Our faculty is dedicated to resident education, and it is our wish to see our residents grow in their clinical, scholarly, and professional pursuits.
